message: First time to me to notice that "HTML class names are case-sensitive" so I decided to share it.
story: Ahmed Magdy shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Are class names in CSS selectors case sensitive?
caption: stackoverflow.com
description: I keep reading everywhere that CSS is not case sensitive, but I have this selector .holiday-type.Selfcatering which when I use in my HTML, like this, gets picked up <div class="holiday-type

data.message:
Classes and IDs *values* are case-sensitive ... Attribute themselves aren't, like if you tried to style an input with a "required" attribute ... If the attribute is uppercase like "REQUIRED" you can still select it using input[required] and it will be picked up by the element (check out this fiddle http://jsfiddle.net/2rrt00e9/)

To comply with XHTML standards all your tags, attributes (not talking about values here) should be in lowercase ... As a general rule, any value that's not meant for displaying info (like contents of data attributes if you are depending on its value for instance) is better to be written in lowercase ... This is like a convention a lot of people used to follow ...

All the talk about using a flag for case-sensitivity in CSS selectors level 4 is pure non-sense .... trash talk, I don't believe there is any need for that. Just because you can add whatever to standards doesn't mean you should. Better push in other directions that are truly needed.

*edit: rephrased a few words and corrected a wrong information. Thanks to Ahmad Fatoum

Yup, XHTML was a standard that meant to make HTML comply with XML standards ... Like having quotation marks around attributes, attributes should always have value (hence the odd required="required", tags should always be closed and a lot of other things
Well, they way you phrased it in the first comment, one would assume it's XML thath requires lowercase, which isn't correct.

I didn't know that, when XHTML came out I assumed from the recommendation that XML require lowercase ... I guess this is the W3C's touch :D More interesting information I found here http://stackoverflow.com/a/1075011/497828
we need more posts like that :)
